												I have not always considered myself a carebear.  I cut my teeth like a lot of people on games like Ultima Online, which will always hold a special place in my heart.  The constant danger from both the environment and other players made life precious and your actions have weight.  A simple trip to go mine ore could often become a danger filled epic as you struggle against both PK's, Enemies of your clan and even your own personal nemesis from time to time.  Along came Everquest a few years after UO to instead focus in on working with your community members rather then fighting them.  While nothing works 100%, players gradually stopped killing each other in favor of deeper loots.  Still something was lost to us UO fans.  Danger was no longer quite as "Real"  Since then I have treadmilled through im sure just about every major AAA MMO release trying to find a home to bring back that excitement, I had always steered clear of DF because frankly I was pretty sure I would get my ♥♥♥ handed to me.  I was right! About 2 weeks ago though, I decided why not give it a try.  After all, at one point I use to handle myself and I did still PvP in games like WoW for instance.  I am no coward, in real life having retired from military service and some real life experiences that would make half these hardcore gamers wet themselves in fear.  I could handle this.  Boy was I about to be suprised. (in a good way)            Okay, so anyone who has played Darkfall Online:Unholy Wars, or its original incarnation knows one thing about it.  It is a very unforgiving, political, no handholding environment.  You start off in the newbie area related to your race (which sadly has been turned into humanesque models for hit box purposes) choice is by far as close to a handholding experience as you will get.  A very almost subtle tutorial (very reminiciscent in feel to EVE Online's Turtorial) will guide you through the basic ways to gain prowess in the game, which is accomplished by completing certain feats within the game (think achievements for all you console junkies out there)  The thing I love is, right off the bat with very little effort you can build yourself up well enough to create just about anything you initially need.  Virtually everything you do gives you prowess so just playing the game and setting out on planned adventures can help you get to certain goals.  There are no levels in Darkfall, you literally just  build the character you want through the skill and power choices you make.  The only skill you really have to grind at are the crafting skills which to be honest are just like any other crafting skill in other titles, its all about harvesting the resources and creating objects.  A salvage system lets you take even the loot you get off creatures and turn into something useable.      So my first few days in Darkfall were pretty uneventful.  The global chat is filled with the usual batch of idiots with nothing to say, and the smattering actual helpful people.  I will say this with absolute conviction, you will not find much help out of global.  No, global chat is pretty much redundant.  Trade chat is much more focused however.  Where I think AV did it right is, they instead implemented the Mentor program.  With the mentor program you will actually have a older player assigned to you, to help you with advice and  some have even been known to do more then that.  That being said, my only expectation was knowledge and my mentor gave me that in droves.  I did do a bit of research prior to coming in the game on the clans present and had already chosen my clan before coming in, but from what I understand, a lot of folks end up joining the clan of the mentor.  Either way, you will have to type and actually communicate with people if you want half a chance of getting anywhere in DF.       I made myself some chain armor a crappy greataxe and decided to see what the PvE is all about in Darkfall.  I found it suprisingly fun and pretty evenly balanced in terms of my characters abilities to handle, and you figure out real quick if a creature is beyond your abilities in DF.  Again no hand holding.  There is no level marker to tell, you simply have to go in and give it a go.  To be honest, I LOVE THIS.  It has brought exploration back into my gaming world.  The world is a dark and sinister place and Agon, filled with fallen ruins, serene environments and caverns and holes in various places does its best to push that envelope.  I even managed to find places that veterans of the game were unaware of.  That is pretty awesome.    The only thing I have had a hard time with has been managing to stay on the hit box.  I am partially handicapped and my reflexes are somewhat impeded but once I got some practice in, it is easy enough to stay on target.  PvP though provides a whole different dimension to combat.  The custom roles patch that just went in effect has certainly made things interesting.  Now gone is a lot of the cookie cutter class runs of the past as players new and old are trying to figure out what they feel comfortable with.  I am sure it will not take long for the flavor of the month meta gamers to start touting ultimate builds, but for now everyone is kind of playing around with the improved options which honestly give a TON OF FLAVOR to character building.      To fans of old school DaoC, I would highly encourage you to check out DF:UW.  It really has that old frontier feel that a lot of us were big fans of.  It also does one thing that very few PvP games do.  It gives me a better reason to want to defend my clans holdings, to expand them.  I am motivated beyond just racking up points so I can prestige etc.  I have a stake in this world, and I think that is important, because even DaoC to some extent failed to bring that to the table for me.  Yes, I have spent most of my gaming time as a carebear, more interested in the crafting and pve content then pvp.  But Darkfall has changed that for me.  While I am still not 100% hardcore into PvP, I do like mixing it up and I feel a real reason to do so.  There is something to be said for that in a game.  So this has been a old carebears review of why I think Darkfall Online:Unholy Wars deserves a second look, a third look.  Yes it is tough, but thats good, challenge yourself.  If you just put the time and effort in you will not regret it.  Now is a great time to jump on board as well, not only is the playing field slightly more even as everyone figures out the impact of the custom roles patch but AV is running a new player special as well.  I hope this mini review is helpful to others like me that sit somewhere in the middle between hardcore gamer and casual gamer.

												To me, the game and the concept are amazing. The hardcore pvp aspect sounds amazing. I love the open world pvp. At the same time, the way they set up their "feat" questing/leveling system is just SUPER grindy. Just GRIND GRIND GRIND. Just takes up more spell slots on your already limited circular spell bar thing :|The crafting is pretty deep, but at the same time simple which I like. Anyone can eventually craft great gear. But then again you have to spend TONS of hours farming, and it's not like most MMO's where you walk up, harvest a vein of ore and now you find another. Instead you will spend 5-10 minutes smashing on one ore vein or hacking at one tree, or collecting one plant. It's extremely boring and not well thought out. I honestly didn't feel like I spent most of the game doign anything but hammering rocks/collecting plants. Or at the funnest of times grinding mobs which spawn all to damn quickly, you can barely skin their corpses before the next wave is butt ♥♥♥♥♥♥ you.The pvp was about as boring, I was in a fairly large guild and when a seige came, it ended up being me standing on a wall slinging spells from half a mile away hoping to even damage someone. It would literally take my spell a good 4-5 seconds before it even got to where the enemies were standing doing the same thing. And while their melee characters ran around 2 shotting anyone they could get close to. I had a lot of mixed feelings seeing as I liked a ton of the ideas this game had, it just seems like they executed almost ALL of them extremely poorly, turned the game into a super slow paced grind fest.

												I've owned DFUW since before it was on Steam.  I don't play through Steam so my playtime is not represented correctly.  I have over 1000 hours pretty easily.Best current mmo because they put 6 things together that no other mmo does.  Many games can claim to do a couple of these things better, but no other game is the complete package.FPS style combat with friendly fire, Not tab target, you actually have to aim and lead targets.Territory control with player built cities and siege warfare.Full loot PvP.  Take everything from your enemy, whether it's weapons, armor, treasure or even a warship.Seamless world, no instances.Classless characters, you don't have to be just a healer or tank, do everything you want to do or specialize as you please.Nonlinear character progression with no levels, do whatever you want to do to build up your character and never be left out because you aren't high enough level to venture into any zone or dungeon.Darkfall also has arguably the best ship combat in an mmo.  Ships come in all sizes, from rafts and fishing vessels to man-o-wars that are 10x the size of a house and require dozens of people to operate optimally.Darkfall is made by a small indie company so the interface and controls can take a little getting used to, but once you've reconfigured your binds and settled in, it's not much different from any other 1st/3rd person action game.  It's based on territory control and clan warfare so don't plan on playing solo for too long.  There are plenty of clans in the game that are always looking for new members, it's easy to join up and start warring with other clans right away.

												Before I start this, I should note that I don't feel I have played long enough to make a full review, I just know in advance that I wont have time to play the rest of the free week. So take these as more of a set of notes, than any type of in depth review.Darkfall Unholy Wars is a decent mmo, it really is but I have got to say its really only worthwhile if you are part of a niche hardcore pvp mmo audience. If pvp and crafting are not your focus in an mmo, this is probably not the mmo for you. Character creation is decent/ average, you get to chose your race, skin tone, facial features, ect. But once you get in game you start to notice the differences almost immediately. The game is action based so you will have to aim your attacks and spells in first person, or third person if you are a melee class. The actual combat reminds me a bit of the combat in Elder Scrolls Online, but alot less polished feeling. The User Interface I have got to say is one of the worst I have ever seen though. Even after I learned where everything was in it, actually using the UI just felt terrible. I have a certain respect for anyone who plays the game regularly without customizing it in some usable way. The game uses a classless skill based system, and you will probably spend a lot of your time grinding crafting materials and skill experience/ points. I believe there is a way to do this AFK, though aside from just setting your character to mine, chop, fish or what have you, and walking away (or alt tabbing) I don't know of any way to do this.As for the appearance of the game, I have got to say graphics wise its nothing special. Its got a non cartoony High fantasy style. The Graphics themselves look to be from anywhere between 2005 - 2008 if I where to guesstimate. It does not look bad but I would not say its good looking either, just average I guess. I dont know what else to say about the game besides I reccomend any new players to join a clan. Do not try to figure the game out solo, it will be so much harder, and take so much longer if you dont have help. Dont be afraid to ask for help in game, like what something is or what a stat does, ect. Also watch out for trolls.Overall I have got to say I recommend this game to hard core pvp and sandbox mmo fans. There is a good deal of fun to be had if you end up liking the game. IT does have its issues, and I do not know how the populations is during normal game hours (I am playing during the free week so there are a ton more players atm). I wish you all luck!

												This review is for people who are familiar with Eve Online and I will use it draw comparisons.  I will first list the features that both games have, which is the primary reason why I like these games.Player controlled cities/holdingsPlayer controlled buildingsPlayer built shipsFull crafting system where just about everything in game is built by players.Full market system with buy/sell orders.PVP is mandatory, if you go out to kill some mobs you always have to be watching your back.You will lose your loot if killed by a player to that player.Personally I played Eve Online for about a year and half, and I only had one single problem with.  The downtime is excruciating most of the time.  10% of Eve Online is great fun, because very interesting things can happen in a player controlled world like that, however the other 90% can be extremely boring.  Darkfall addresses this problem quite well.Darkfall has many systems that encourage players to leave relative safety of clan holdings.  This encourages players to leave there cities to accomplish many tasks.  There are city levies, which take time to be emptied and you must protect yourself or take the risk of gaining massive loot.  Treasure maps can be found which will give you some basic direction of where to find actual good loot drops to dig out of the ground.  Just recently while treasure hunting I was forced to walk through enemy territory to find the loot.  These are just a couple of ways that PVP is encouraged and exploration as well.  The map is big enough to provide relative enough safety and you can always hide behind a rock and hope they don't see you.The sieges and boat system adds to the complexity of the game.  Of course this game is for hardcore players, most people are not going to like it.  Before finding Darkfall I was playing Rust and trying to get into DayZ.  I was interested in the idea of fearing for my life every time I go out.  Darkfall does this in ways I wasn't expecting.The progression system makes the gameWarningsDon't leave relative safety with any items you are not willing to lose.  Bank your loot often.You must find a group and have a mic, use teamspeak and find a decent clan, most will accept noobs.  Plenty of terrible clans out there, but plenty of good ones too.  Finding a good clan makes or breaks this game, it's an MMO not a single player adventure.  Join one as soon as possible, they can help you learn much more quickly.  If you join Darkfall planning to play solo, while possible, it is not going to be fun in the end.  I play solo half the time until I'm needed for a fight or raiding party, however I'm generally always in teamspeak while playing unless I'm simply harvesting resources or crafting.There is a lot of grinding, if that's not for you then don't subscribe.You cannot repair armor or weapons, once it is destroyed by durability it is gone forever.  However this keeps the market stable and makes it so resources are always in demand, Darkfall has one the most lucrative and stable markets of any MMO including Eve Online because of this.Crafting can be very tedious, but partly what I like about this game is harvesting resources and crafting is very easy to do while watching Netflix or otherwise doing other things online.This is not some tab based skill cooldown game like WOW, it is live action and fast paced meaning FPS skill is more important than your actual build in some ways.The interface is very old school and takes a lot of getting used to, however I grew to actually like it.Graphics are not amazing nor are they terrible.TipsMake plenty of bags and organize your loot in your bank.  It's the games way of managing the massive amount of items you will find.Save all your loot you get.  It's almost all useful in someway or can be sold on the market.  Salvage items you don't need.Set out to finish your feats, it's the easiest way to gain prowess.Gather resources on your downtime while watching Netflix or surfing the net.  Every little thing you do in this game gives you prowess which can be spent on any skill or stat.

												Great game with much potential. Things I like:-Massive world (about 40km2)*You also need to actually explore, since world maps starts blank. You can vaguely see where land ends and sea begins as well as general look of the terrain from under the blackness. Mobs spawn in certain areas like wooden forts or caves (map has marks for those areas. You can also make your own tags if you find something interesting.-Lore *Well, it exists. You need to dig into the wiki or ask the players about it, but a little mystery is nice too. Still, it could use a some padding.-Openworld pvp (you also drop your items if you get ganked(killed by player while down)/release your spirit after death. You can get them back if you reach your grave before it's looted)*Also openworld ofc. A bit overwhelming at first, but it's nice to set your own goals and plan your own adventures)(Quest system is still under development)Constant threath of other players also makes it much more rewarding to bring a haul from adventure back to the bank (there are also banks around the world near chaos bindstones (respawn/recall points) but they are unprotected. I haven't experienced much playerkilling around them though).Being chased by another player can be quite thrilling too. It's possible to escape from even high level player since all mounts run at the same speed (there are speed enhancing skills that make you faster than mount, but you can outrun even them if you get enough headstart and manouver well enough (not too much zigzagging to dodge projectiles and using terrain as cover.)Currently there are no stealth skills, but if you crouch in a bush or hide behind objects and use 3rd person(there is 1st person too, obviously), you can "manually" sneak around players too. Crouching also makes much less noise when walking. You must target player/npc directly and be within certain range to see it's UI.-Localized markets (still under development, partially implemented)*Similiar system like EVE online has. You need to travel to different markets to physically get the items you buy-Monthly subscription*Yes, It is a good thing. I haven't seen any bots, gold spam or even cheaters. It also keeps the game fair, which is essential for such pvp oriented game. Upkeep isn't free and this is the most fair way to get money for it. Free to play works really well for some games, but this isn't one of them.-D.U.E.L  subscription extension item*Similiar to PLEX in EVE. You can buy it with real money and sell it for ingame money, meaning that it's possible to play the game for free. Gold isn't too hard to get. Some mobs drop a lot of it and you can also get lucky with chaos chest (random chests around the world that may have huge amounts of gold or almost none. They may contain other nice stuff aswell. You find tons of them if there aren't much players around.)-Upcoming feature (Relics: Grand items that you can either haul to your clan's church, which gives clan a worldwide buff, or you can take it to demon altar and destroy for prowess reward. (Prowess = xp. There are no traditional levels in DF. You buy and upgrade skills and attributes with prowess. First levels are extremely cheap but it gets more expensive higher the skill is. Currently 100 is max for everything. Each level makes skill a little more powerful)-Graphcis and music*While graphics may not be highest AAA quality, I think it's very atmospheric. Reminds me of Morrowind. Music on the other hand is epic.-Clans *or guilds, how ever you want to call them. Much of the game is built around clan system. They can capture villages (in which you can build your own house) and Cities. Citys have allkinds of nice stuff that clan can build there: crafting area, resource nodes for faster and safer gathering (there are also safe areas in which you can harvest, but clan nodes always give full quality resoruces, while regular nodes may give inferior quality stuff, which you can use to craft reqular quality resources.), skill trainers and shops. They are closer to more exiting places than safe zones too. -EconomyIt's completely player driven. There are only few essential items that can be bought from npc like basic tools and spell ingredients.Mobs drop low quality equipment and you can find better items from random chests/equipment racks around the world. Rest you have to craft or buy from market.Mixed opinion-Resource gathering from nodes*It's time consuming and uneventful(thought it also gives you prowess, especially if you get rarer items while harvesting), but it's easy to do other things while waiting for iron node to get picked or wood to get chopped. Gathering makes distinct sound which can be heard throught video if you set your volume levels right. If the sound stops, you know it's time to switch node/tool or regain stamina. This gets a little harder if there are multiple harvesters around you, but then you just need to be more vigilant. In areas outside safe zone this is a lot more dangerous, since other players can attack you, but with large group emptying nodes is much faster and safer.I think there could be somekind of minigame for harvesting, but that might not be that good idea in the end.Things I don't like-Inventory system (Devs are making an overhaul to it)*Very crude and quite hard to manage if you are in hurry. At least there are bags which greatly help organization.-Small playerbase (Game needs more publicity. More positive recommendations and/or less negative (and useless, like mere "this game sucks!" reviews) would help too.)* This can also be a benefit for new player, since if there are less players around you can gather prowess and resources more freely and thus become more pvp viable faster. The game can be enjoyable even with small playerbase.-Easy to get away with player killing. *I don't think there are any penaltys for doing so, expect for being tagged as playerkiller. I hope devs will take a look of this at some point.> This is not handholding game like wow or many other mmo's there are. While this means the game may be harder for you to understand and play, it also means greater satisfaction once you start to see how things work. Also the game wont treat you like an idiot. On my experience the community has been friendly and helpful towards new players. There are also currently 2 major clans that actively recruit new players and teach them how to play. There is also mentorship system. Experienced player can take apperentices and teach them how to play. They also get rewards if their apperentice gains enough prowess. <There are other stuff too, but this is all I can think of currently. If you decide to try the game, be patient and don't give up. Also watch some gameplay videos first to get better general idea about the game.

												I hesitate to write a review so early in the piece, but I was very pleasantly surprised by my first session of Darkfall.  I knew what I was getting into because I played Mortal Online for about a year in about 2010, when the game was very buggy and had broken features.  I'm told MO has improved since. The environment looks empty, but that's the nature of these games.  People try to stay hidden out of safe zones unless they are looking for action or have nothing to lose.  I played during the Aussie day on the US server, and there were plenty of players around in the town, and a couple in the wild to.  One, who came upon me trying my hand on Goblins and who I basically fled from until I realised he wasn't going to pinch my meagre noob stash, ended up inviting me to his guild.These styles of game are superb, fantastically immersive, and great fun whether you like to play a killer, an empire builder, or a running away artisan like myself.  I hope you decide to buy this game and graduate from themeparks into a world where you can truly leave your mark.

												 I have been searching for something new in the MMO genre for a long long time. I was a vanilla WoW player.. I really loved the world pvp in that era of world of warcraft. I have always felt instances and battlegrounds etc ruin the immersion and potential fun of pvping in mmos.Enter Darkfall: Unholy Wars. There are no instances. It is a PVP based mmo where every bit of pvp that happens in the game is somewhere in the world. PVP is cutthroat like those games of yesteryear. When you kill someone all of their loot drops on the ground. It is a sandbox mmo... you can go anywhere and do just about anything... you can customize your class as much as you want. There are not levels, just incremental "prowess" of which you only need about 30k-40k to be pvp viable. At time of writing this review I have 46k prowess and I have killed people with as much as 200k prowess. It took me about a week to get to this high in prowess which consisted mostly of killing different camps of monsters throughout the game.I could go on describing the game, but I think anyone reading this review will know if the game is for them or not. Gaining prowess is a grind, I find it far superior to questing which there isnt a single one of in this game.  Combat is completely skill based (no tab targeting what so ever.) meaning you will need to be comfortable playing first person shooters to enjoy this game. I see myself playing this game for a long time to come... I just wished I had discovered it a lot sooner.

												I'd give DFUW a rating of 8/10 but that being said this is my favorite game and there just isn't any better for full loot PvP/sandbox gaming.I've had an active sub for 2 months. I was inactive for the first 2 weeks due to computer issues. I've made it to 125k prowess and I feel strong. Its enough to max 3 weapon skills, my boosters in strength and dex, my base stats to 100str, 100dex, 70int, 80wis, 2 ults, a handful of leveled spells, and 2 crafting masteries. I'd say the key to get to where I am is to find at least one other solid player that you can farm with alot. Having a farming friend makes the spawns trigger faster, makes kills faster, and gives you a buddy to help you to your feet when you get knocked to the ground. Each of you pick a few different crafting skills to train (as this gives you self made gear whenever you want it, and also prowess) and trade each other for the things you need. Either way, the key is to have at least one trustworthy buddy to go farm with. Its also a decent way to make friends and get invited into a clan. Running into other players:I typically run into 3-12 instances of seeing other players doing ♥♥♥♥ per day I play. Requisitions, farming mobs, sea scrapping, etc (although its not uncommon for me to spot you, then slink off sneaky-like and get away) ((makes me wonder how many times I had unseen eyes looking me over)) keep in mind my playtime ranges from 3-10 hours per day depending on work and other IRL factors. Status of the player base:I see tons of new players joining. Near starting zones I see new players with less than 1k, less than 5k, and less than 20k (prowess) that I've never seen before running around (particularly Amurran, wolfland capital) *Note, Ork lands seemed fairly empty when I cruised through there. (a good place to start without alot of people killing you early on perhaps?)Not to mention that players that took breaks or quit return often. New content draws people back, as does free-play days. Especially after the release of DUELS, (Tradeable 30-day subscriptions players can buy from AV and then sell for gold or loot to players) which allow people with too little cash or unintentionally expired subscriptions a shot at re-subbing for free (well, about 70-90k gold average)Status of the community:Oh dear. Read through the forums and you'll find all sorts of...strongly expressed opinions. Unfortunately most of those strongly expressing their opinions are also closed-minded to other opinions. So, be prepared for alot of loud and ignorant rants/complaints. Some are valid sure, but sift through those at your own risk and judgement. Anyway, I've read through a bunch and my opinionated summary is as such: Darkfall is an ever changing game ran by an Indie and somewhat small time company called Adventurine. Its come a long way since Darkfall Online, DFUW's predecessor. AV hasn't always been the best with customer support but they're loads better now. People have always said AV doesn't listen to their customers well enough, but they have greatly improved. Keep in mind, that if you look through the forums you can find 100+ submissions for "How to improve" or "How to fix" things in darkfall. The trouble there is that there is 100+ posts! AND- reading through them myself, I saw many that were too poorly worded to follow fully, another handful that were terrible ideas (IMO), and another handful that I agree with but perhaps not the majority of players would, (or AV) SO! You have alot of ♥♥♥♥♥ing, about things that bother a few people. But to fix it, you'd ♥♥♥♥ off a bunch more, so AV's hands are tied in these issues. Keep this in mind if you dare to sift through those posts. If you care to comment on them, take the time to speak clearly and consider how it would fit in with the rest of the game. Dont be discouraged by these posts. And try and imagine from the content of the post, who the poster is. I see alot of rants that I'm assuming are just cry-hard kids. -- Not worth reading. A Short Story of my start:Start in Wolflands with my brother. Read a few guides, tested a few mob types, decided to wield greatswords. (whoops, IMO) Basically build for warrior type. Goals at this point are to get enough Rank Zero gear to not be naked, get spells like Vamp Strike, Power Attack, Barrage, Reinforce, Bandage so I can last longer (lots of damage buffs/lifesteal, some heals and a damage resist buff) Why goblins? -They drop all Rank 0 armor and weapons, arrows, gold, reagents to cast spells, potions, food and some teliportation tools like portal shards and runestones. Also, killing goblins satisfies 5 feats at the same time: Humanoid, goblinoid, creep, varmint, freak feats, for lots of bonus prowess per kill once feats are complete (((Do not focus mastery feats, focus habitual feats. Habituals are earnable weekly, some daily, for bonus prowess for completing the habitual feat requirement. Focusing habituals will get you all your master feats in due time, its very time efficient))) (@ 5k prowess)Trouble is, goblins got boring and easy by the time I finished goblinoids and humanoids. So, I moved on to Gnolls, which drop way better. Avoid Gnoll vilegaunt/butcher spawns till 40k+ prow or with a friend or two. However the Gnoll shaman, tribesman, and fighters are all relatively easy and again they drop pretty sweet. (Coal, Rawhide, up to 3 piles of gold, teleport stuff, pots, plus all Rank Zero stuff) These classes of gnolls can be attempted almost at any prowess level, but I do recommend goblins first. Then, it was on to Elementals. (I was 20k my brother 40k prowess) Elementals, Ice, Earth, Air, and Fire -- all have their own feat plus the master elemental feat which all elementals count for. Ice, Earth, And air are all doable at 20k+ prow with a friend. Disclaimer- Elementals shrug off elemental magic, so mages are gonna have a unprofitable time casting spell after spell for little effect. Also, elementals hit hard with their spells and comparatively soft with their melee. Mages should consider equipping a shield and a favorite 1 handed weapon at this point and maxing that skill for elementals (and in general)At this stage I was 40k prowess, and I started looking hungrily at the bigger gnolls. I'd already considered them best loot for easy kills/low prowess, and those big ones dropped much nicer and even expensive things! So, after buying more skills, upping their levels, and etc, My brother and I moved to Gnoll Vilegaunt spawns. Those ♥♥♥♥ers will be tough at first, so bring a friend or two. Their drops are great enough I still farm them as my favorite mobs (there are spawns that spawn Gnoll tribesman, shaman, fighter, butcher and vilegaunts, with an additional vilegaunt/butcher spawn ON TOP OF the 5-pack spawn, so lots of the tough guys often = fast loot when you can kill em all) Also, I should add that mobs can hit each other, so make them do that alot and crouch behind cover to avoid arrows (big mobs in your face count as cover from the ones behind them, they'll shoot their buddies while trying to hit you) I killed a handful of other mob types, (look up the troll dungeon for more easy prow with decent loot (but a decent chance to run into other people) I wont tell you my full story with every mob I've killed in detail but I can say -- look at the PvE feats and target some mobs that have good rewards. There are guides elsewhere that breakdown their ease-of-kill and drops. Read those if you want more info than this long ♥♥♥ post.Making Friends: So, the best thing you can have in DF is a buddy! I've stated so already, you'll grow super slow solo. How to make friends? Well, there is the recruitment sections, you could try that, or invite friends to play darkfall, or... Go knock people over! But, instead of ganking them and looting their grave, Revive them and invite them to farm or hang out.

												Darkfall Unholy Wars review from a new player (started playing beginning of Feb 2014):The main purpose of this review is to help you determine whether or not darkfall is for you, as I understand this game is not for everyone. Will YOU enjoy it? Read below and find out!First of all, you need to understand Darkfall is a pure HARDCORE PVP game.Apart from the starting/safe zones. you can attack anyone / anytime / anywhere (even party members and guildies!)When you kill a player, you can loot anything that is currently on him (BUT items deposited in banks are safe).That being said, in order to enjoy this game you need to:1. Love PVP in its most cruel & hardcore form2. Love world PVP as there are no BG's or arenas.3. Join a guild (a clan) as roaming alone will get you nowhere (at first). Only by joining a clan you will understand the true purpose of the game.4. Be ready to do a bit of grinding in order to level (acquire prowess) - being in a clan will help you become PVP ready much faster as guildies can help you with feats/lend you fishing trawlers (to powerlevel)/and provide you with tips and better understand of the game.5. Rebind you keys to your liking.6. Get over the odd interface.IF your focus is PVE or questing or if you dislike PVP or are a very casual player or a loner by all mean stay away from this game!Do I personally enjoy the game? Here's my experience:I started playing this game about a month ago. The first time I logged on I was a bit turned off by the controls and the interface. With proper keybinding I was able to get over this. I then started doing a bit of reading in order to understand better the game and learned how to build my caracther (a skirmisher). I then started gathering prowess by all possible means (mobs grinding & skinning, gathering, crafting, explorations, prowess monolith, feats, etc...)At this point I was getting more confortable with the game and felt it was time for me to start PVPing. I tried roaming around the world by myself but without success. Either i'd meet over geared player and would get crushed or I would simply not find anyone to fight... Until I joined a clan (Zerg), got summoned to my clan keep, hoped on Teamspeak... and started raiding other clan keeps!I can now say that I'm truly having a blast playing Darkfall, as nothing beats the feeling of running around with a dozen guidlies / traveling by boats in order to lay an attack on other clans. I still have a lot to discover & understand but so far as a PVPer by heart I'm really enjoying this game.SUMMARY:This game is great IF you enjoy HARCORE WOLD PVP and if you are ready to take the time to understand the game, join a clan and farm/grind a bit in order to become pvp ready (you'lll need around 15k-30k prowess, which is easily attainable within a week or two with proper clan support - lots of clans are currently recruiting new players - ie: Zerg clan). Trawling (fishing on a boat is for example a very fast way to gain prowess, but beware of pirates!).I hope you will find this review helpefull, hope to see you in game,Bull Rott

												A huge world with a full loot mechanic and the ability to kill anyone and anything at any time outside of safe zones. Its basicly a giant sandbox meaning you can just start doing whatever you feel like from the start. You can start harvesting reasources or killing mobs. Or an archer, elementalist or a primalist. Since they removed classes in this game you now have the ability to mix and mash any of these and more that you like so the one character restriction limit they enforce upon you doesn't really matter because of this. If your looking for a giant sandboxy hardcore themed mmo with full loot and have some friends to join you then this game is probably worth a shot with the $15 price tag. If you are someone who gets really attached to items or plans on going solo then your chances of enjoying this game are a bit lower since this game is heavily group oriented. This doesn't mean you can't play alone though it will just take longer to earn prowess, upgrade your character and you have the risk of being overwhelmed by groups of players. 												Okay I will start of by saying this is EASILY one of the best MMORPGs I have ever played... I've played everything from Runescape, World of Warcraft, Ultima Online, Guild Wars 1 & 2; you get the point.  With that being said I'd have to say my top 3 were Runescape, World of Warcraft, and Ultima Online as my number one favorite.  If you have ever played Ultima Online or Runescape you will feel the nostalgia almost immediately.  This is definitely a 3d version of these games with amazing graphics and much more.  I see a lot of the negative reviews about this game and it is kind of disappointing because a lot of them didn't really even give the game a chance... some only having half an hour on account.. I see a lot of complaints about the user interface etc.  But isn't a game more about gameplay? I mean 2 of my all time favorite games had very sh*tty graphics...  I won't deny the fact that the user interface could be a LITTLE better and the game still has few flaws but I mean every game is going to have issues, it doesn't matter what it is.  If you thoroughly enjoy PvP in games and hell even some good PvE this is definitely the game for you...  Some of the mechanics in this game are some that I have never seen before such as player owned cities, hamlets, villages, sea towers, housing and so on..  I've never played a game where you could fight other boats, destroy them, and then take the fight to the water to fight to the death.  This is definitely one of the most exhilerating PvP games I've ever played and I get an adrenaline rush from time to time.. If you try the game you'd understand.  This is a full-loot game where you lose all of your items when you die but don't let that scare you because there are safe zones, banks, and so on.  I won't deny the fact that this game is a little tricky to get used to but if you give the game a chance and actually try to learn it with an honest effort, I can promise that anyone willing to do that would not regret it.  My best advice to anyone reading this review would be to give the game a shot and find some players willing to help in game because there are plenty of them willing to help newbs learn the ropes, myself included.  I'll end this review by saying don't let the full-loot scare you away because there are ways around it and you can farm in safe zones in order to build yourself a nice little bank before you're ready to get into the actual game.  Give'r a whirl, take it from someone who actually has a lot of hours on the game :) hope to see some more newbs!

												This is solely my own opinion, Caveat Emptor! [Latin, Let the buyer beware.]Pros:- Market Sales: Items and Gold go directly into your Avatars Bank, no mail system!- Active Environments- Harvesting (Harvest doesnt require user to continue to re-click)- Discounted Subscription Rates- Nightly 1 hour Maintenance Cons:- Steep Learning curve - Time Investment- Loading Screen Times overly long  *ALT-TAB*ing = High chance of game crashing completely.- Steam Overlay problems- Not being able to craft when having a shield equipped- No taxi service- GUI: Side of screen (switches), icons, quite small.I have played mmo's since they were text only games, been on design teams, and beta tested the original Project Entropia, now Entropia Online(link at bottom), back in  early 2001 on through to Gold and beyond.  My mmo experience spans years of playing across multiple platforms and operating systems, I tend to have more then one installed to get what I am looking for when the time arises, though to me this game fails to bring anything "ground breakingly new to the table", this is not the first mmo to have "non-Tabbing" it's certainly *Not the best PVP* that I have played, it's not the "largest loaded map...", in the mmo world, it has a lot to offer and a new player will never fully realize the potential of the game without investing in it.  Below is a big read and a partial experience of my hours of game play during the Free time provided by DFUW and Steam Hosting.My rig hums along nicely and I enjoy most games with decent to ultra settings, without taxing my system. Perhaps DFUW's lower fps and constant dc's may be due to *bugs with the Steam Overlay meshing with DFUW, I know I was affected by the endless screen shots bug and needed to turn off Steams Overlay, to get to playing a bit smoother. I also deleted all 1378 screen shots!  The loading screens were a bit...long, and I found out early on that I could not simply "ALT-TAB" out during loading screens to desktop without crashing the Program fully. I had a chance to try out spell caster, skirmisher and settled on the hack n slash nature of the warrior class, for the most part the tutorial was helpful, until I crafted too many items and no longer had the starting gold to complete making a Saddle, and thus breaking my Tutorial, forcing me to find an alternative way to continue.  On a side note I was not able to actually craft any items with my Skirmisher class, I had tried re-logging which I disliked due to the wait times and no ALT-TABing, only to finally find out in the Chat channel that it is a known Bug that you may not craft whilst you have a shield equipped... A helpful player /W Whispered me from my query's in the chat channel, and offered to give me the gold I needed to complete the tutorial, I declined as I would like to know how to make in game currency and get out of the situation on my own...  the suggestion was to harvest ore from metal deposits in the safe zones, and sell that...   ... Thus I went through the new player city mining metal ore deposits until my pickaxe broke!  So I went to the general store, to buy a new one, and double clicked a few times, before I realized I was buying pick axes per double click it was too late, at 5 gold each, I now had 2 new pick axes and 1 gold.  I took my Iron Ore and Inferior bits off to the Smithy, I was able to craft once - as the crafting costs 1 gold per craft.   At this point I felt the only way to make money now would be to sell it on the Market and get what I could...  Unfortunately I did not have enough in game money to use the market left, and this left me to offer a sale via Trade Chat.  I checked market prices for Iron ore at 22g per unit that day, I offered a Trade of 7 Iron ore for 100g, I asked in main chat and was told to bother the people about trades in Trade chat, after re-posting several times over 40 minutes, a player whispered and offered to help me out, they did not want my Iron ore, or anything else, they game me 2,000 gold some advice and told me to pay it forward.I enjoyed the market system quite a bit once I had some money to play with...   Not having items sent to a mail box and or money was a real treat!  The game play reminded me of early console "Bards' Tale" *STYLE* Games, with accuracy of attacks being counted for where you swing your weapon, and/or if you actually hit your target with a projectile, be it magical or otherwise.  Thus the PVP was no big thing for me either, perhaps my years of Project Entropia playing, makes me think less of DFUW, play style....  there are countless games out there not just the ones on steam, and not just in the America's!  There are non-English mmo's that would blow your socks off, that you may never realize exist.I explored out of the safe zones, I died out of the safe zones, I PVE'd and PVP'd, I worked with a group to farm prowess, both acting as support and skinning team, I had an enjoyable experience in that style of team play, of which I have had in most other games, thus team play is what I want out of any mmo....  I joined a clan.  I like to do some solo PVE as it gives me a chance to see the world and learn first hand knowledge, I had my request in to join, and went with the farming group even though I was still solo, after 40 minutes I had gained +400 Prow and the system was shutting down for nightly 1 hour maintenance. Our group disbanded... a day later my application was accepted, yet I could not get the attention of anyone in the alliance to tell me how or if I could port directly to the main clan city... in the end I took everything off my character, except the starting weaponry you are forced to keep, and a skinners' knife (I chose to bring), and set out... great way to explore btw - the Green Shield soon was blinking and a 10 second Warning flashed on my screen and counted down... I passed mountain ranges, snowing passes, water falls and fields of blood... the red shield got up to the roman numeral V before I even got half way down the map, leaving a slug like trail of visible land behind me....  at one point another player rode up behind me on a silver bear... I had pressed "Num Lock" and just let my avatar run whilst I worked on my laptop... the player stopped then turned and rode off... I explored a few fields, some structures etc when I fancied a look around, it took nearly 2 hours to *run* to the clans property, and another 5+ minutes to get to the city, then I spent maybe 15 minutes trying to figure out how to get inside!!  I used markers in the city to note where the clan bank, mines, farms, timber lot etc were so I could find them easily.    Not having the ability to taxi from one place to another is a big drawback to me, only being able to be bound to 1 stone also was useless after binding myself to the clans stone, as the only way to get to a world wide market was in a major city, as the clan market was just for the clan!!!  In the end I spent easily 90% of all my time Gathering and hitting Mobs to gain the much needed supplies, armor, gold, prowess, to advance in the game, was it enough to get me to shell out $20.00 a month after exchange rate and taxes?  No.Ending prowess 8.7k, ending gold 27k, lots of banked resources.The real drawback for me was TIME INVESTED to ENJOYMENT EXPERIENCED. The scale is heavily weighted on the Time Investment part in this game, however if that makes you happy, go for it... I've invested thousands of hours and dollars of my life in game play, over ten's of years! There is another way to get "real life 3D team experiences".... that though requires you to put some clothes on, shoes too, and head outside, I know that sounds scary, but trust me it's worth every moment of it!Entropia Universe "3D MMO Multi Virtual World Real Cash Economy Experience"http://www.entropiauniverse.com/
